You can start a realtime node using FlushingPlumber @zhxiaom5

Integration tests fail so often that I'm not sure it makes more good than harm to run them on every PR.
Which ones are failing? Maybe we can fix them.
@gianm I didn't see one specific test which fails often. Sometimes JVM crashes. Often hangs.
Hmm, how about collecting failure results for some time in an issue, see if we see a pattern, and if we do then fix it; and if not then find another way to automate the integration tests.
There's already a CachePopulator in CachingClusteredClient, although it's a private inner class. Do you think it's fine to use the same name?
@gianm good point. Renamed `CachePopulator` to `CacheGenerator`.
Thanks @jon-wei. The master branch merged cleanly.

@dclim actually this seems to be solved by [1.10.56](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-12420?focusedCommentId=15976997&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15976997) am giving it a try.

I thought this day would never come.

@nishantmonu51 you didn't mention motivation in the description, but I guess it's so Druid's runtime would be able to treat nulls in a more SQL standard way. Some initial thoughts:

> To match the new semantics we need to make aggregators nullable, where if an aggregator encounters a null value the result will be null value.

If the goal is more SQL-like behavior, you don't want this, since it's not how SQL works. SQL aggregators like `SUM(expr)` skip NULLs but still aggregate all non-NULLs. It's still different from what Druid does though (especially for MIN/MAX where Druid would treat missing as 0 and standard SQL behavior would skip it).

> Backwards Compatibility

You're missing a big one, which is backwards compatibility in the runtime: preserving current behavior where `null` and `""` the treated the same. There's a lot of code out there that expects Druid's null handling to work the way it currently does, and we don't want to break it.

ITKafkaTest - infinite repetition of messages like
```
2017-06-02T17:44:17,098 INFO [MonitorScheduler-0] com.metamx.emitter.core.LoggingEmitter - Event [{"feed":"metrics","timestamp":"2017-06-02T17:44:17.098Z","service":"","host":"","metric":"jetty/numOpenConnections","value":0}]
2017-06-02T17:44:18,668 INFO [main] com.metamx.http.client.pool.ChannelResourceFactory - Generating: http://172.17.0.1:8090
2017-06-02T17:44:18,673 INFO [main] io.druid.testing.clients.OverlordResourceTestClient - Index status response{"task":"index_realtime_kafka_test_0_2017-06-02T17:38:58.540Z_laaaokep","status":{"id":"index_realtime_kafka_test_0_2017-06-02T17:38:58.540Z_laaaokep","status":"RUNNING","duration":-1}}
2017-06-02T17:44:18,674 INFO [main] io.druid.testing.utils.RetryUtil - Attempt[16]: Task index_realtime_kafka_test_0_2017-06-02T17:38:58.540Z_laaaokep still not complete. Next retry in 20000 ms
```

@praveev @jon-wei It looks like #4276 is a regression somewhere else in the code. I'm not sure fixing it in PeriodGranularity is the right place, since it worked fine in 0.9.x
@xvrl believe this was introduced with support for timezone and refactor of granularity on this PR https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3850 that was released with 0.10.0
@drcrallen @leventov does this absolutely need to be in 0.10.1?
@praveev ah yes, I stand corrected, looks like #3850 broke timezones indeed

@gianm this is a bug, while Druid was always required to be **run** in UTC, PeriodGranularity was designed to allow requesting arbitrary timezones at query time and the results returned should reflect the proper UTC offsets in the timestamp. I think this is a duplicate of #4276

In SQL if you have this data

|NAME|ATTR|VALUE|
|------|------|-------|
|A|z|1|
|B|z|1|
|C|z|1|
|D|`(null)`|1|

and do 

```SELECT SUM(value) WHERE `ATTR` != 'z'``` you will get 3 if I recall correctly, where most people expect 4.

Which is not necessarily a good thing.


Here's an example using DERBY embedded:

```sql
DROP TABLE FIRSTTABLE;
CREATE TABLE FIRSTTABLE
    (ID INTEGER NOT NULL GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY (START WITH 1, INCREMENT BY 1),
    NAME VARCHAR(12), ATTR VARCHAR(12) DEFAULT NULL);

INSERT INTO FIRSTTABLE (NAME, ATTR) VALUES ('A', 'z');
INSERT INTO FIRSTTABLE (NAME, ATTR) VALUES ('B', 'z');
INSERT INTO FIRSTTABLE (NAME, ATTR) VALUES ('C', 'z');
INSERT INTO FIRSTTABLE (NAME) VALUES ('D');

SELECT * FROM FIRSTTABLE;

SELECT * FROM FIRSTTABLE
WHERE ATTR NOT LIKE 'z';

SELECT * FROM FIRSTTABLE
WHERE ATTR NOT LIKE 'bannana pajamas';
```
this gives the following:

```
ID           NAME          ATTR          
-----------------------------------------
1            A             z             
2            B             z             
3            C             z             
4            D             <null>        
```


```
ID           NAME          ATTR          
-----------------------------------------

```


```
ID           NAME          ATTR          
-----------------------------------------
1            A             z             
2            B             z             
3            C             z             

```


IMHO this behavior is super annoying and detrimental to the flexible schema approach that druid uses. So I don't think just blindly taking SQL null handling is a good idea.
@fjy I think no, but I don't see problems with merging it, since there are still several outstanding PRs and issues in 0.10.1 which are quite far from being merged/resolved.

I thought this issue was just saying that the interpretation of "null" time zone changed from local time to UTC, when the server is running in local time. Which still doesn't sound like a bug to me, since before and after 0.10.0, the interpretation of "null" time zone is UTC if the server is running in UTC (which it should be). So the behavior didn't change in that case.

#4276 sounds like a different issue to me (although maybe the same underlying cause) and that one is clearly a bug.

@gianm ah, I see, in that case I agree with you. I wrote DurationGranularity as something that was implicitly UTC based, so if we now care about the timezone it spits out, we should explicitly set it UTC, but it was never meant to be timezone aware. The assumption when it was written was that the user timezone was already UTC in the first place. Only PeriodGranularity was designed to allow specifying timezones.
@dclim this should work now thanks !
@b-slim awesome, thanks! 👍 after travis

@xvrl I think your original design is still good. The only change I'd make, if we ever decided to support running in non-UTC time zones, is documenting what the behavior is when the user timezone is not UTC.
👍  from my side for design, i didn't look at implementation but trust that it works

@drcrallen I think the idea behind following a standard is to make interoperability between druid and other system easy, is there a better standard ? 
Also by adding this support it will actually add more flexibility for instance you can elect to replace `null` with empty therefore you `SELECT SUM(value) WHERE `ATTR` != 'z'` will return `4` instead of `3` and vice versa. Anyway i agree with you SQL is not god's word and we can elect to not follow it as it is.

Note, this could be broken up into different patches, but I had written them together and it would take extra effort to pull them apart since they are somewhat inter-dependent and have a shared motivation. I hope reviewing them together isn't too bad, but if that's not possible, a break-up could be one for each of:

- adjusting expression null handling
- adding the ExprMacroTable concept
- adding string return for "expression" post-aggregator and virtual column
- adding the "expression" filter
- adding the new expression functions and macros
- each of the two query changes
- all the SQL changes together

If people feel that is necessary then I'd at least like to have the overall design reviewed first before breaking up the code.
Fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4343
Would be fixed by #4360.

I vote for breaking this PR into multiple smaller PRs, because I'm not going to review this PR as a whole, but I would review some of the smaller parts.

The overall design looks good to me.
@leventov thanks for raising #4359. This is definitely a blocking issue, and maybe we can fix it.
I feel this design is much better than #4207. And I also vote for breaking this PR into smaller ones. It is easy to miss some details when reviewing a large patch as a whole.
LGTM.
Thanks @gianm @jihoonson for review.

This problem must be fixed regardless of we continue to use travis for integration tests or not.

@fjy this is because @hexian55 based his PR on pre-#4348 commit. The assumption is that post-#4348 PRs include that PR, but it may not hold for some PRs in the nearest future. Could be ignored. Travis failure is real (albeit transient) though.
@hexian55 could you please fill CLA http://druid.io/community/cla.html ?

Hi

We've a problem using the insert tools to migrate data from S3 to new druid cluster.
The problem occurs here in S3DataSegmentFinder:90

```
final Map<String, Object> loadSpec = dataSegment.getLoadSpec();
if (!loadSpec.get("type").equals(S3StorageDruidModule.SCHEME) || !loadSpec.get("key").equals(indexZip)) {
```

the problem is that we've a lot of segment that are located on S3 but have not existing value or key in the loadSpec in fact a lot of segment in S3 have an empty loadSpec json info.

This is strange because you even doesn't check this case in the code may be4 you can help me to understand why it's happen

By the way I've add a patch to check this case to prevent the NullPointerException

Thanks
@leventov   it‘s ok

@inneractive-opensrc 
Hi, do you mean you get a null value from `loadSpec.get("type")`? It would be grateful if you submit your PR which fixes this case.

@hexian55 actually i don't think it is a bug as per the comment [here](https://github.com/b-slim/druid/blob/d80bec83ccf4bfaf42d31bcfb0564ee1eba483ca/extensions-core/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/fs/HadoopFsWrapper.java#L41-L41)
Great proposal and +1 on splitting this !

@b-slim  sorry , It seems that the problem is not so simple on the surface,   druid 0.9.2  https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/0.9.2/extensions-core/hdfs-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/fs/HadoopFsWrapper.java   the same as 0.10.0,and my hdfs version not change.
 druid 0.9.2 In my system running normally, but when I update it to 0.10.0, There was an exception like this PR .  and segment write to hdfs failure.
If i change this class HadoopFsWrapper  rename method for this PR, it's will be ok.
I will continue to find the cause of the problem, do you have any suggestions? Or what do you think may be the problem?
@hexian55 what version of hadoop are you using ?
@jon-wei thanks, added null annotations

@hexian55 see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3650 , two rename methods are not interchangeable . similar issue was reported in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3787 . please check all the hadoop jars you have on your classpath.

@gianm @jihoonson : Thanks for the comments have updated the proposal to include your comments. 
@drcrallen: As @b-slim and @jihoonson pointed out following the SQL standard makes it easier to make Druid work with other existing tools. For the above case you mentioned, with the above proposal, the user has the ability to replace null with any default value at the ingestion time and achieve the desired behavior.
Thanks @fjy @leventov @jihoonson @b-slim for reviewing the overall proposal. I will split it into smaller PRs.
@niketh how about the HDFS Puller ? also curious what is the main driver is it perf ? stability ? misc ?
@b-slim HDFS puller already uses directly uncompressing from stream. This PR is a result of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4302
Closed in favour of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4364
ok looks like it is a performance improvement plus making pullers more uniform. 👍
Broken out from #4360.
Broke out one PR into #4365.
Broke out #4366 and #4367 too.
@leventov Addressed your comments.
@gianm @jon-wei I've updated this patch against changes made in #4292. Also, I added an option ```forceGuaranteedRollup``` to ```IndexTuningConfig```.
@hexian55 i am assuming this can be closed ?
could you please fill CLA http://druid.io/community/cla.html ?

@b-slim I done it.
See: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4273
ok  ,  please close this PR
Thanks @b-slim !!
@gianm thanks for review, are you sure about https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4326#issuecomment-304366983? Also pinging @nishantmonu51 again

I think the change in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4326#issuecomment-304366983 is fine, because the base64 encode should return a byte array in ascii encoding, and decoding ascii as utf-8 will work as expected.
how about check for `mapreduce.jobtracker.address ` as well ?

@gianm @drcrallen, I see, yeah, to be fully backwards compatible the places at query time which treats empty string and nulls as same will need to have two separate code paths based on a druid runtime property e.g druid.null.behavior by default it will treat null and empty strings as same and preserve the current behavior and users can set it to 'sql' to get the new sql behavior. 

I also feel that having two separate code paths and behavior at lots of places may not be a good and will lead to confusion for users in long run and I would propose to move to sql behavior in future major releases.
Also updated the backwards compatibility section in the description
Filed https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4372

@b-slim ok, added that one as well.

in the long term, I think that if conditional is probably not needed anymore. it was added there to workaround a hadoop issue where it wouldn't propagate the real number of reducers but just 1 all the time when local job tracker was used.
